title: Obituary: Former Sunderland Defender Alan Black
description: Roker Report pays tribute to former player Alan Black, who passed away earlier this week.
fullText:
Everybody at Roker Report was saddened to learn of the death of former Sunderland player Alan Black, who passed away recently at the age of 82. The following is an updated version of an article that was originally published in 2024 to celebrate his 81st birthday‚Ä¶

Having joined from Dumbarton Alan Black provided cover mainly for club stalwart Len Ashurst, which in turn enabled John Parke to take over from the injured Cec Irwin, yet the sixties signing didn‚Äôt disgrace himself in Sunderland colours and would go on to enjoy a more prominent role at his next destination.

Born in June 1943, Black grew up in Alexandria ‚Äì the same western Scotland town as Bobby Kerr. Having begun at Drumchapel Amateurs, as a youngster he turned down the opportunity to play for Blackpool and opted to remain at semi-professional Dumbarton instead so that he could continue his engineering apprenticeship. Once his studies were done though he accepted the offer of a month-long trial at Roker and before it was even complete had agreed to leave the Sons and join the Lads on a permanent basis.

Moving in September 1964 when the board were overseeing the majority of first team affairs prior to the appointment of George Hardwick, Black made his debut the following February with something of a baptism of fire, but despite facing a Manchester United side that included the great ‚ÄòTrinity‚Äô of Bobby Charlton, Denis Law and George Best, he helped secure a clean sheet and narrow victory against the Red Devils ‚Äì fellow Scot Harry Hood getting the only goal in front of a 51,000 strong crowd.

Three days later Sunderland were in the capital to play Fulham and despite defeat he gave a solid showing. This was to be Black‚Äôs last game of 1964-65 however, and it wasn‚Äôt until October that he resurfaced, deputising for Ashurst once again in another away match at West Bromwich Albion.

Now working under his countryman Ian McColl, he followed that up with another appearance seven days later, when he came on for the injured Jimmy Montgomery in the last few minutes of a thrilling win over Nottingham Forest. Martin Harvey went in goal in place of Monty, with Black slotting into the defence after becoming only the second ever substitute in a competitive Sunderland fixture ‚Äì he may have also been involved in midweek too had the League Cup permitted substitutes, as fellow Parke was forced to limp on in a tie against Aston Villa despite taking a heavy whack.

There were to be two more outings for Black during the campaign, both coming away from home in a draw at Sheffield United and then a during a defeat to Liverpool. Having played the full 90 at Bramall Lane he then came on from the bench again on Merseyside the following weekend, and whilst the Lads were already trailing when introduced this proved to be his final game for the club.

Black left Sunderland a little over a week before the 2nd anniversary of him signing full time. One of several reserves that McColl was willing to part with as he looked to raise funds for incoming deals, the ¬£9,000 Norwich City forked out soon looked like good business ‚Äì their new arrival debuting later that evening in a 2-1 win at Northampton Town. His Canaries bow proved to be a good precursor to the rest of his time at Carrow Road too, where he became a crowd favourite and featured in the Division Two championship winning season of 1971-72.

After playing over 200 times for the team, including five instances of him lining up against Sunderland, Black returned to Dumbarton in 1973 but was soon forced to retire due to knee problems. The Norwich title win, which had included a return to Wearside during the run in for a 1-1 draw, meant the club had reached the topflight for the first time ‚Äì a feat that contributed towards Black subsequently being inducted into their Hall of Fame and gladly accepting many subsequent invites back to Norfolk.

It was in his native Dumbartonshire region though where he lived, remaining there once his football career was over and making use of his familiarity with the area by becoming a taxi driver. Rest in peace Alan, and best wishes to his loved ones from all at Roker Report.

*The photograph at the start of this piece shows Alan celebrating the Durham Challenge Cup that he won whilst playing for Sunderland reserves during 1965-66. The team beat West Auckland 3-2 in the final at Darlington and alongside him are Keenan (l) and Campbell (r).

title: 2 Up, 2 Down: Sunderland See Off Palace For Another Home Success!
description: Our writers highlight the positives and negatives from the Lads‚Äô 2-1 home victory over the Eagles!
fullText:
I thought Hume played very well.

Whenever people discuss a predicted team, it‚Äôs Hume that gets the push. He‚Äôs not always guaranteed his right back berth but it‚Äôs not a problem as he can slot in at left back or more recently, in midfield. He was also the creator of a few deft moves and had one or two chances himself.

You can‚Äôt keep Northern Ireland‚Äôs man of the moment down. Mentions as always for Nordi Mukiele, Granit Xhaka and Enzo Le F√©e, but I was impressed with Hume.

Another victory from a losing position ‚Äî epitomised by Brian Brobbey, who got his usual battering but kept on going and got a very deserved goal.

This team doesn‚Äôt give up. Big hearts, big engines and big desire.

We were very open at the back, especially in the early stages of the first half.

Crystal Palace had several breaks that on another day could have seen us 0-2 down before we got going. Luckily, as usual, R√©gis Le Bris and the team sorted it out and we became more solid and more assured.

The first few home games this season had most people staying until the final whistle, but the early leavers are back.

They stop in the gangways and block people‚Äôs view, then everyone has to stand. It‚Äôs a free country, but does anyone leave the theatre or cinema early?

An amazing winner from Brobbey underlined his value to our team.

He battled throughout, showing his strength and skill. It‚Äôs really important to have the outlet that the big Dutchman provides ‚Äî and the finish off the underside of the bar was truly remarkable.

This was another game during which nobody could be faulted for their performance, and the team we support is so much more than a group of talented individuals.

We have players that genuinely care about the city, the fans, and where we finish in this league.

I love that about these players ‚Äî they sweat blood for each other and that‚Äôs very reassuring.

Is there a pattern developing that to start dominating home games, we need to go behind? Six of the eleven home games have followed this script.

Our head coach has a Ph.D. in sports performance so he may have some insights he can share. As a fan, I find it quite relaxing to follow home games, with two rules: A. Don‚Äôt worry if we concede first, and B. We‚Äôre not going to lose anyway.

This is an amazing way to enjoy and take in matches.

I can‚Äôt come up with anything negative. This was a much-needed and deserved victory; we‚Äôre getting our best players back and it all bodes well for the rest of the season.

Happy¬†times to be a Sunderland fan.

Historically, going 0-1 down at home would be the beginning of the end.

However, this team is different and the resilience demonstrated to not just get back into the game but to then go on and win it was admirable. What certainly helps, though, is the crowd, as nobody was getting on the players‚Äô backs when we conceded.

Instead, there was an encouraging roar and it helped solidify our unbeaten home form.

Considering that we signed Brobbey on deadline day, it‚Äôs incredible to think that he‚Äôs turning into one of our most important signings of the transfer window.

His strength and ability to pin in three centre backs is undoubtedly a huge reason why we got three points this afternoon ‚Äî and that‚Äôs without even talking about the finish, which was absolutely sublime.

A class footballer and I can‚Äôt wait to see how he continues to develop.

I can‚Äôt help but feel that at times, that we‚Äôre in a time machine and have been transported back to League One when it comes to referees. The ‚Äúmain event‚Äù energy that‚Äôs surrounded the last few officials has been suitably minging to watch.

If there‚Äôs one thing that‚Äôs bound to get on the collective tits of everyone at the Stadium of Light, it‚Äôs inconsistency.

This referee personified that and some of the decisions that Jean-Philippe Mateta was able to get compared to Brobbey was just ridiculous.

When we‚Äôre 2-1 up in a close game, I find it baffling that anybody would leave.

We ask the team to give 100% until the final whistle and given that we just have to sit there, it‚Äôs not difficult to ask for everyone to stay until the game ends, not least of all to give the team the credit and appreciation they deserve after such a fantastic performance.

Our big number nine was my man of the match. His hold-up play got us up the park and his battle with the Palace defenders rarely went their way.

How he managed to score a goal by putting the ball over the keeper and under the bar is beyond me.

Another great performance, with a goal and a hell of a shift put in.

The man covers every blade of grass on the pitch and is as strong in defence as he is in attack

After his panenka nightmare, he‚Äôs recovered and kicked on massively ‚Äî and the love for Le F√©e is clear from the songs we all sing.

The chances for Brobbey and Trai Hume earlier in the game should‚Äôve been converted ‚Äî both great moments for us but not taken advantage of.

We didn‚Äôt suffer from that lack of clinical finishing, but on another day, we may have done.

The gaffer left it until about ten minutes before the end before putting any fresh legs on.

Given the way we harried and pressed Palace, we may have closed the game out sooner with fresh limbs, but what do I know that the French professor doesn‚Äôt?

I‚Äôm clutching for a second ‚Äúdown‚Äù, because to be honest, there aren‚Äôt many options.

The Stadium of Light is still a fortress. We‚Äôre the comeback kings ‚Äî and we‚Äôre in the top eight and above the scum.

Not sure it gets a lot better than that.

Brobbey was fouled all game and got no protection from the referee, but ultimately had the last laugh by scoring a winner which had people scratching their heads asking ‚ÄúHow did he do that?‚Äù.

He was a handful from start to finish; a proper, old-fashioned centre-forward, bullying the Palace defence. His footwork was a little awry in the first half, as he had a few chances where the ball got under his feet.

However, his persistence paid off with a fabulous winner in the 71st minute, as he dinked the ball into the net from five yards out.

How did we pick him up for such a ridiculous fee?

¬£9.5 million plus add-ons seems like absolute daylight robbery for a player who provided the assist for Enzo Le F√©e‚Äôs opening goal and should‚Äôve been awarded a penalty when Romaine Mundle was bundled over in the penalty area when he received another cross from Mukiele.

Mukiele and Brobbey were given yellow cards for telling the ref to stop the constant and persistent fouling by Palace‚Äôs defence.

Brobbey was constantly being fouled and manhandled ‚Äî so much so that I got a little concerned that he might be provoked into kicking out. Thankfully, he kept his head and had the last laugh, but the referee had to give our players better protection. He also missed a stonewall penalty as Romaine Mundle was bundled down in the box after receiving a cross from Nordi Mukiele.

Granit Xhaka turned in an uncharacteristically hesitant display in the middle of the park and almost gifted Palace an opener.

We looked indecisive and tentative at times, but things improved in the second half as R√©gis Le Bris had looked quite annoyed as he headed down the tunnel for the half time break.

title: Matchday Musings: This Is ‚ÄòNew Sunderland‚Äô ‚Äî Galvanised By Conceding!
description: This is ‚ÄòNew Sunderland‚Äô. We are a side whose heads are incapable of dropping, and as a result, seem to almost be galvanised by conceding.
fullText:
After two weeks of back-page murmurs and speculation, Sunderland finally ‚Äòjoined the chat‚Äô in the January transfer market, announcing the acquisition of Jocelin Ta Bi ‚Äî a reportedly crafty winger from Israeli side Maccabi Netanya.

Fashionably going by his first name on the back of his shirt, √† la trendsetters ‚ÄòVirgil‚Äô van Dijk, as well as most of the Brazilian national side, the forward has averted any prospective mix-up with our other right-winger Chemsdine Talbi, much to the relief of commentary teams across the land.

This Christian-name-on-back-of-shirt fad had me thinking: imagine our entire squad followed suit, all in the name of self-promotion and personal brand.

We‚Äôd have a trio of Brian, Simon, and Wilson leading the line ‚Äì names of middle-aged fellas you‚Äôd find perusing the Daily Mail down at any Wetherspoons, lapping up the latest Reform UK drivel. Not forgetting their mate, Dennis, who, unlike the rest of them, still has all his hair and teeth.

Yet, perhaps the best of the lot would be the outgoing Blondy. Presumably, a player named after either Debbie Harry or his definitely-not-dyed peroxide hair.

Anyway, enough on player first names and more on Saturday‚Äôs game with Crystal Palace: a side who ended last season with an FA Cup triumph, and started this campaign with a Community Shield win and European qualification.

On paper a very solid outfit, but contextually anything but. They are a club seemingly in free-fall, with stalwart Marc Gu√©hi poised to join Manchester City, while boss Oliver Glasner tendered his resignation in midweek.

That said, while R√©gis Le Bris has worked wonders in distancing us from that Sunderland-y reputation that once preceded us, Yeremy Pino‚Äôs opener following our pretty solid start was very on-brand for the Sunderland of old.

There were several dips in concentration, with Robin Roefs being called into action on a few occasions, including to deny Jean-Philippe Mateta early on. A rare defensive lapse saw Palace‚Äôs only real creative outlet on the day, deftly place it beyond Roefs. It was a pretty sloppy goal to concede, made more frustrating by the fact that it was straight from a set-piece.

Nevertheless, this is ‚ÄòNew Sunderland‚Äô. We are a side whose heads are incapable of dropping, and as a result, seem to almost be galvanised by conceding.

It took just three minutes for Enzo Le F√©e to restore parity. Following an intricate bit of interplay down our left side, the Frenchman guided Nordi Mukiele‚Äôs low-driven cross into the bottom corner with effortless finesse.

After the break, there was only one team out to win it. Our second-half display really exhibited us at our very best; defensively solid, tenacious in midfield, and potent in the transition.

In the 71st minute, Noah Sadiki‚Äôs line-splitting through-ball put Brian Brobbey in on goal, and with a sublime stroke of his right boot, our ¬£20 million Dutchman half-scooped-half-thumped it over Dean Henderson, who was left helpless as the ball satisfyingly sailed in off the bar. 2-1.

While our visitors probed in the dying embers, we remained dogged at the back, and could so very easily have made it three via a sumptuous back-to-front move which ultimately saw Trai Hume clip the top of the crossbar.

With three points under our belt, breaking the string of five games without a win, and protecting our unbeaten home record, this was another superb afternoon on Wearside.

Rumour has it that Brobbey would not have had to be surgically removed from his back if he had not been substituted, as Maxence Lacroix would have had to be removed due to the defender‚Äôs persistent, unpunished fouling of our number nine.

Brobbey cramping up after his goal was actually due to the fact he had been supporting the body mass of two men all game.

Although Granit Xhaka had a poor afternoon by his impeccably high standards, I was, once again, left speechless by the collective effort of the team. From Mukiele‚Äôs marauding runs down the centre of the pitch, Noah Sadiki‚Äôs unrelenting press, and Le F√©e‚Äôs class to Omar Alderete‚Äôs trivela cross, I thought there were standout moments for all involved.

A victory that propels us up to eighth, three points off fourth and back above those lot up the road (even if it‚Äôs only temporarily) ‚Äî the boys in red and white have delivered once more.

title: Sunderland‚Äôs Comeback Win & City Revival: A Perfect Afternoon
description: As I headed home, I was left with one overriding impression ‚Äì Sunderland AFC and the city the club calls home are marching together in lockstep towards a long-overdue renaissance in their fortunes.
fullText:
We normally drive up from Yorkshire for home games but, for a variety of reasons, I attended the game against Crystal Palace on my own. A quick check of rail fares meant that the Grand Central return ticket was less than ¬£20 (courtesy of being an old git with a Senior railcard) so, accompanied by a Sainsbury‚Äôs meal deal and a couple of cans of JD and Coke, I took the relaxing option to head north.

Arriving in Sunderland, I followed the crowds heading for the Keel Crossing. It has been several years since I made the journey from the city centre to the SoL on foot and, for someone who grew up in Seaburn and Roker in the 60s, when the sides of the Wear were dominated by the shipyards of Austin & Pickersgill, Doxfords and others, it was something of a revelation!

As I headed towards the recently opened bridge, the evidence of redevelopment was all around me. New buildings and sites surrounded by Heras fencing, awaiting construction, were everywhere.

The new bridge afforded a wonderful view of the iconic Wearmouth Bridge, through the crowds of supporters making their way to the game, whilst the Stadium of Light itself appeared even more imposing in the distance, from an angle I have never approached it from before. At the other end of the bridge, much of the derelict buildings that had blighted the area for so long have either been refurbished or replaced ‚Äì the tasteful redevelopment of the historic Sheepfolds Stables is particularly impressive. Of course, the area has been neglected for decades, and there is still much work to be done.

The return journey in the dark, with the opposite bank of the bridge all lit up, around City Hall, was the perfect illustration of how bright the future of the city is looking.

In between, there was the small matter of a fixture against Crystal Palace, who should have been in disarray after the loss of captain Marc Gu√©hi and the announcement that Oliver Glasner would leave at the end of the season. It proved to be far from the case, with the physically imposing Jean-Philippe Mateta proving a real handful for Dan Ballard. The French striker hit the back of the net with a beautiful piece of control leading to a lethal strike, only to see his effort ruled offside.

At the opposite end of the pitch, Brian Brobbey must have thought he had mistakenly wandered into an MMA cage, as he was repeatedly pushed, pulled, and held without evoking any interest from referee Rob Jones.

A failure to clear the lines after a corner ‚Äì which came after Jones awarded a contentious free-kick to the away side ‚Äì led to Palace opening the scoring, and it looked like the Lads were in for a difficult afternoon. But, with Enzo Le F√©e pushing up closer to Brobbey, a well-worked cross from Nordi Mukiele found the mercurial little Frenchman. The defenders were already drawn towards Brobbey, leaving Enzo to stroke the ball home emphatically to level the scores, before half-time.

Sunderland started the second half much more aggressively. As the rough treatment of Brobbey continued, referee Jones‚Äô already limited control of the game threatened to disappear altogether, in a flurry of yellow cards. But the burly Dutch striker would have the last laugh. Noah Sadiki burst forward, driving at the Palace defence before chipping the ball towards Brobbey. Just as he had done against Arsenal, he deftly flicked the ball over the advancing goalkeeper and into the net, before collapsing with cramp into the advertising hoardings, in front of a delirious home end.

Sunderland continued to press and Trai Hume was denied by Henderson and the bar, much to my disappointment as I had a bet on the Irishman to score!

Mayenda replaced the tiring Brobbey and as Palace pushed forward unsuccessfully in search of an equaliser, both he and Dan Ballard were denied from close range by Dean Henderson. Dennis Cirkin replaced Romaine Mundle in the dying minutes ‚Äì the young winger having shown that he is adapting to the demands of Premier League football, linking up effectively with Sadiki and Reinildo on the left, and contributing defensively. Chemsdine Talbi is due back after the AFCON final but he has had little game time in the past few weeks, so having other options is essential for Le Bris.

There was a particularly significant moment as the players left the field. Normally the celebrating fans sing in praise of Granit Xhaka ‚Äì instead the strains of ‚ÄòWe‚Äôve got Le F√©e‚Äô rang out in unison, his misfortune in the Brentford game banished to the annals of history. Afterwards, he spoke about how important the support of the crowd meant to him, a salutary reminder of how much we react as fans can impact our players.

Another comeback win, up to eighth place in the League, unbeaten at home, another three points on the board and just seven more needed in 16 games to reach the magic 40-point mark ‚Äì all in all, a very satisfactory afternoon‚Äôs work by the Lads. For a returning son of the city, it was equally pleasing to see the upturn in the area which surrounds the Stadium of Light.

As I headed home, I was left with one overriding impression ‚Äì Sunderland AFC and the city the club calls home are marching together in lockstep towards a long-overdue renaissance in their fortunes.

title: Barcelona‚Äôs midfield puzzle: Academy prospects at a crossroads
description: One confirmed exit and several unresolved situations have left Bar√ßa navigating a familiar balancing act.
fullText:
FC Barcelona are used to conversations about patience when it comes to young midfielders. This winter, that patience is being tested from several angles at once.

The most jarring case is that of Dro Fern√°ndez. The 18-year-old has opted to trigger his ‚Ç¨6m release clause this January, a move that caught those inside the Ciutat Esportiva off guard. His departure is particularly stinging because his trajectory under Hansi Flick was pointing upward. Flick took him on the preseason tour, handed him a senior debut, and trusted him with starts against high-level opposition like Atl√©tico Madrid.

Flick was reportedly ‚Äúfurious‚Äù to learn of the decision. Recently, he said it was one of the biggest disappointments in his life, as Deco had been working behind the scenes to secure a renewal. But the outside interest proved too much, and the decision is already made. Dro has agreed a move to Paris Saint-Germain, bringing a swift conclusion to months of speculation.

Dro‚Äôs exit may not be the last for Barcelona‚Äôs midfielders. For Marc Casad√≥, the situation remains complicated. Despite being one of Flick‚Äôs early success stories, even earning a Spain call-up, the return of Frenkie de Jong has pushed Casad√≥ to the side. The youngster‚Äôs role has shrunk. This season he has logged 871 minutes across 19 appearances, starting 10 times and being substituted at half time on two occasions.

Last summer, Barcelona were prepared to entertain a ‚Ç¨30m offer from West Ham, only for Flick to intervene. Now, the player‚Äôs own stance has shifted.

According to Marca, Casad√≥ is increasingly open to a move to protect his spot in Luis de la Fuente‚Äôs Spain squad ahead of the World Cup. Atl√©tico Madrid are watching closely. Flush with cash from the ‚Ç¨40m sale of Conor Gallagher to Tottenham, Diego Simeone is looking for midfield reinforcements, and Casad√≥ fits the profile.

Marc Bernal presents a more nuanced case. After losing a year to a cruciate ligament injury just as the Flick era began, his return in September has been handled with caution. With only 273 minutes across 12 appearances, Bernal was considered a potential candidate for a January loan. Girona emerged as a primary suitor.

However, a recent Copa del Rey start against Racing Santander may have changed things. Bernal played an hour, and despite the physical toll, the experience was enough to convince him he can still contribute at Bar√ßa. Mundo Deportivo reports that Bernal is now leaning toward staying.

De Jong and Pedri remain locked as the starters in the midfield two, plus there‚Äôs Gavi‚Äôs return in the long run. And with Ferm√≠n L√≥pez and Dani Olmo vying for the spot behind the striker, a place also sometimes occupied by Raphinha, it‚Äôs not easy to get minutes there, either.

Having already lost one young midfielder to the transfer market, Barcelona will be eager not to lose any more.

title: Patriots-Texans kickoff time today: TV channel, schedule, live stream to watch Sunday NFL divisional playoff game
description: Here is all you need to know about when the Patriots-Texans game will kickoff including broadcast info.
fullText:
Patriots-Texans kickoff time today: TV channel, schedule, live stream to watch Sunday NFL divisional playoff game originally appeared on The Sporting News. Add The Sporting News as a Preferred Source by clicking here.

The 2026 NFL playoffs continue with the Divisional Round. The Wild Card Round is in the rearview, and both the Patriots and the Texans are still alive in the hunt for the Lombardi Trophy.

The Patriots, who entered the postseason as the No. 2 seed in the AFC, advanced to the Divisional Round thanks to a 16-3 win over the No. 7 Los Angeles Chargers. Quarterback Drake Maye threw for 268 yards with a touchdown and an interception. He also led the team with 66 rushing yards on 10 carries.

The Texans came into the playoffs as the No. 5 seed. They went on the road to face the Steelers in Pittsburgh. It was a close game throughout as the Texans struggled to get going offensively. They finally turned it on in the fourth quarter and used two defensive touchdowns to win 30-6.

The Texans had lost six straight road playoff games, but finally ended that streak with the win over the Steelers. The Texans will look to continue that momentum with another road playoff game against the Patriots.

Here is everything you need to know about the Patriots-Texans kickoff time today.

Patriots vs. Texans kickoff is scheduled for 3 p.m. ET on Sunday, January 18. The game will be played at Gillette Stadium in Foxboro, Massachusetts.

Patriots vs. Texans will air nationally on both ESPN and ABC. Joe Buck will handle the play-by-play with Troy Aikman serving as the color commentator. Lisa Salters and Laura Rutledge will be on hand giving sideline reports.

Those who want to stream the game can do so with Fubo or the ESPN app. Fubo carries both ESPN and ABC in its channel lineup, and is currently offering a free trial.

The game will stream live on the¬†ESPN app¬†and on¬†Fubo, which offers a free trial.

The Patriots and Texans Divisional Round matchup will be live on SiriusXM. The Patriots broadcast can be found on channel 225, while the Texans broadcast will air on channel 226.

Get SiriusXM for free for your first month.¬†Listen to live NBA, NFL, MLB and NHL games, plus NASCAR, college sports and more. Stay updated with all the news and get all the analysis on multiple sport-specific channels.

title: Talking Points: Sunderland Get Back To Winning Ways Against Crystal Palace!
description: Phil West looks at the main stories from the Lads‚Äô victory over the Eagles ‚Äî an impressive and key win!
fullText:
After a Christmas and New Year run that hardly represented a ‚Äúslump‚Äù but was marked by one or two less-than-convincing displays and culminated in a disappointing defeat at the hands of Brentford, this felt like an ideal opportunity for the Lads to rediscover the winning habit, given that our immediate run of fixtures feels extremely favourable and could essentially see Sunderland edge over the safety line with ample room to spare.

Doubtless reinvigorated by last weekend‚Äôs FA Cup success and with Noah Sadiki and Reinildo returning to the Stadium of Light following their AFCON odyssey, R√©gis Le Bris‚Äô men recovered from the concession of a strange-looking goal from Y√©remy Pino to overturn the deficit with strikes from Enzo Le F√©e and Brian Brobbey, and adding to an ever-growing list of Crystal Palace problems in the process, with manager Oliver Glasner already on the way out and captain Marc Gu√©hi seemingly bound for Manchester City.

Ahead of the game, I felt the visitors from south London weren‚Äôt to be underestimated ‚Äî this division has a habit of punishing such mindsets ‚Äî but despite falling behind, it was hard not to be impressed with the resilience and focus demonstrated by Sunderland, and after an energetic, potent and generally dominant second half display, we ran out as deserved winners against a side for whom choppy waters may lie ahead.

If the signing of the powerful Dutchman from Ajax represented something of a gamble during the summer transfer window, he‚Äôs starting to repay the transfer fee and then some, because this was as dynamic, impactful and downright brutal a display as I‚Äôve seen from a Sunderland striker in years.

It wasn‚Äôt just the goal (itself a very well-taken second half strike that gave us a lead we would never relinquish) ‚Äî it was the way he set about the visiting defence, rarely letting them settle, holding the ball up and bringing his teammates into play ‚Äî as well as taking more than his fair share of the lumps along the way.

To my eyes at least, Brobbey seems to relish such battles and when he left the pitch to a standing ovation late in the second half, it felt as much in response to his all-round display and the sheer workload he‚Äôd blasted through as it did for what proved to be the winning goal.

He‚Äôs looking ever more like a perfect fit for this side and he‚Äôs becoming a very popular figure with the red and white faithful. Keep going, Brian!

‚ÄúYou want a response? I‚Äôll give you a response!‚Äù

OK, perhaps I‚Äôm being presumptuous and putting words into the mouth of the French magician but after recent events and all that talk about how he ‚Äúowed us‚Äù (he didn‚Äôt, by the way), why should we not celebrate the fact that this sublimely gifted footballer both plays for and has clearly taken to life at Sunderland AFC as much as any other player in the squad?

He slotted home the equaliser following a sharp Sunderland break and as is generally the case every time he takes to the field, he was more or less everywhere, carrying his share of the load in both attack and defence ‚Äî importantly so, because Granit Xhaka and Noah Sadiki weren‚Äôt at their best yesterday ‚Äî which went a long way towards the eventual victory.

If I was a young Sunderland fan, I‚Äôd be starry-eyed when watching Le F√©e. As it is, I‚Äôm thirty six, I‚Äôm increasingly grumpy and I don‚Äôt move very quickly ‚Äî and I‚Äôm still starry-eyed when I watch Le F√©e. He‚Äôs just so good.

He got a warm reception when he came out to warm up and as R√©gis Le Bris has previously disclosed, Neil remains a professional presence within the home dressing room at the Stadium of Light, but it‚Äôs also hard to escape the reality that this chapter appears to be drawing to a close and that the former skipper will soon be moving on to pastures new.

Sunderland AFC is now a very different club to the organization that Neil played such a key role in restoring to its place among the elite of English football, but if this was the latest waypoint on his long goodbye to Wearside, there was no hint of bad feelings or bitterness, and in an era when players often don‚Äôt think twice about throwing tantrums if things don‚Äôt work out behind the scenes, that says something about Neil‚Äôs approach to football and his respect for our club.

title: On This Day (18th Jan 1994) Lee Leaves It Late As Lads Get Job Done
description: Mick Buxton‚Äôs Sunderland needed a replay plus extra time to overcome their FA Cup foes.
fullText:
Having played, rather infamously, in 1974 and then as recently as 2014, Sunderland and Carlisle United are no strangers to FA Cup meet ups. The clubs were even drawn against each other for two years running in 1994 and 1995, with both ties having to be settled via replays at Brunton Park ‚Äì the first instance of which took place on this day.

A hard-fought draw earlier in the month On This Day (8 January 1994): Buxton‚Äôs Boys look to avenge Stokoe‚Äôs Stars | Roker Report meant the sides had to do it all again in Cumbria, where heavy rain and a rapid frost thaw had left the pitch in a less than ideal condition. Nevertheless, referee Roger Dilkes was happy for the match to start having carried out an inspection earlier in the day, although the arrival of strong winds come kick-off did make the already difficult conditions even more tricky to cope with.

The weather proved to be a factor in not only the game itself, but Mick Buxton‚Äôs team selection also; young forward Craig Russell had picked up a knock at the weekend during Sunderland‚Äôs game against Middlesbrough, and having taken the playing surface into consideration the manager felt that Lee Howey‚Äôs more physical approach would be better suited. Howey was on a high anyway having scored the header that had settled the Wear Tees clash, and with Don Goodman and Gordon Armstrong already sidelined through injury the last thing the squad needed was to lose Russell for a period by forcing him into a prolonged slog on a mud bath.

Russell was instead brought on to see out Sunderland‚Äôs passage into the next round having just seen them take the lead, although it had been a long time coming admittedly. Despite Carlisle‚Äôs Division Three status they dominated the first half, and having already given the Lads a scare on Wearside they looked a decent bet going into the break. Simon Davey and David Reeves both looked dangerous, whilst Rod Thomas was also a threat, but they were unable to find a breakthrough and as time marched on the visitors came on strong.

Since Buxton had replaced Terry Butcher in November Sunderland had only lost twice, and their new found resilience meant the Blues eventually ran out of steam before being forced to sit back. A quality move involving Gary Owers, Richard Ord and Phil Gray led to a period of pressure after an hour and ten minutes later Gray came within a fraction of scoring having been put through by Brian Atkinson. Still, it needed extra time before the crucial goal, with Howey sweeping an Ord knockdown from a Martin Smith corner into the net to send the away support behind the goal wild.

The 4,000 or so travelling fans made up around a third of the total attendance, and a number of them ended up on the pitch amidst the celebrations. His decision to pick Howey vindicated, Buxton brought Russell on shortly after the action had recommenced ‚Äì meaning that the ‚ÄòJarra Arra‚Äô could now run at a tired defence in the closing stages and look to keep possession well away from his own goal. The tactic worked a treat and whilst it might have been a grind at times it was enough to give Sunderland their first FA Cup victory over Carlisle, who 20 years earlier had been the ones to bring their defence of the trophy to an abrupt end.

Sunderland: Chamberlain; Owers, Bennett, Melville, Ord; Atkinson (Russell 106‚Äô), Ferguson, Ball, Smith; Howey, P. Gray Unused: Norman, Ma. Gray

Brunton Park, attendance 12 771

title: Man Utd star may have played his last OT match as Sky confirms Juventus interest
description: Juventus have reportedly joined their rivals Roma in the race for Manchester United striker Joshua Zirkzee, who could genuinely leave the club this month.The Dutchman has been struggling for minutes s...
fullText:
Juventus have reportedly joined their rivals Roma in the race for Manchester United striker Joshua Zirkzee, who could genuinely leave the club this month.

The Dutchman has been struggling for minutes since the start of the season. Following the arrivals of summer signings Matheus Cunha, Bryan Mbeumo, and Benjamin Sesko, he found himself at the bottom of Ruben Amorim‚Äôs attacking pecking order, only earning a starting role when some of his teammates were missing due to injuries.

The former Bologna star was hoping to make a good first impression on the new Man Utd boss, Michael Carrick, but he wasn‚Äôt even in the matchday squad for the Derby victory over Man City.

ESPN journalist Rob Dawson revealed that the striker‚Äôs absence is due to a knock he received in training earlier this week.

In addition to providing updates on the player‚Äôs condition, Dawson also revealed that the Netherlands international could still end up leaving Man Utd before the end of January. This was also echoed by Dutch journalist Joost Blaauwhof.

‚ÄúJoshua Zirkzee is missing from the Manchester derby due to injury,‚Äù he posted on his X account.

‚ÄúThe striker is sidelined for a short period and could already have played his last match at Old Trafford if action in Italy picks up soon. The possibility of that is considerable. The Manchester United striker is reportedly keen on joining AS Roma.‚Äù

(Photo by Michael Regan/Getty Images)

Zirkzee‚Äôs possible move to Roma has been well-documented over the past few months, as the Italian capital side has been keen to add him to Gian Piero Gasperini‚Äôs ranks.

But according to Sky Sport Italia journalist Gianluca Di Marzio, the Giallorossi could have company in the race, as Juventus are also considering a move.

The transfer market insider insists that the Turin-based giants are determined to sign Crystal Palace bomber Jean-Philippe Mateta, who has also been on Man Utd‚Äôs shortlist, but they have identified Zirkzee as a fallback option.

It should be noted that Carrick decided to drop Sesko from the starting lineup on his debut, which could spell further bad news for the already-frustrated Zirkzee.

The English head coach is seemingly in favour of fielding Mbeumo in the No.9 role to make room for Amad Diallo on the right wing. The Cameroonian responded well to the change, scoring the all-important opener against Man City.

If this trend continues, Zirkzee might find himself third in line for the striker role in a season where United hardly need extra depth due to the lack of commitments. Therefore, the Dutchman might soon be marked as surplus to requirements, opening the door for a return to Italy.

title: Lakers player grades: L.A. loses big in Portland while short-handed
description: The Lakers were very short-handed on Saturday versus the Trail Blazers, and they ended up losing again by a wide margin.
fullText:
The day before the Los Angeles Lakers' Saturday matchup against the Portland Trail Blazers, Luka Doncic was ruled out due to groin soreness. Prior to the opening tip of that game, they got more bad news when it was revealed that starting center Deandre Ayton and backup center Jaxson Hayes also wouldn't play.

With Austin Reaves still sidelined due to a gastrocnemius strain, the Lakers were in a very difficult situation against a Portland team that had won eight of its last 11 games.

Los Angeles was competitive early, but a 15-2 Trail Blazers run put them up 40-27 at the end of the first quarter. They shot a whopping 22 free throws in the first quarter, and in general, that first period set the tone for the entire evening.

The Lakers were never able to mount a serious challenge, as they ended up losing, 132-116. It was their fifth loss in their last six games and their 12th loss in their last 21 contests, as well as the second game in a row they gave up over 130 points.

They simply got outclassed in almost every category. They let Portland shoot 52.3% from the field and 38.1% from 3-point range, and they got outrebounded by 15 while giving up 27 second-chance points. It's becoming a broken record for the Lakers ‚Äî they continue to put up a weak level of resistance defensively while often getting outplayed in the effort categories.

They now have a 24-16 record and remain in sixth place in the Western Conference, and they're just half a game ahead of the seventh-place Phoenix Suns.

Smart did plenty to give the Lakers a chance to win this game, at least offensively. He took 17 shot attempts, which was a new season high for him, and made nine of them while going 4-of-6 from 3-point range, giving him a team-high 25 points. He also had two rebounds and one steal, but he had no assists in 25 minutes.

The Lakers needed an all-hands-on-deck effort, especially offensively, in this game, but LaRavia didn't pull his weight. He got off only two shot attempts and missed both of them, and he scored just two points on free throws. In 28 minutes, he contributed five rebounds, four assists and one steal.

Kleber has barely scored or even looked to score this season, but early on, he was aggressive offensively. He scored nine points in the first quarter and ended up with 11 points on 4-of-8 field-goal shooting, and he also had five rebounds, one assist and one steal in 21 minutes.

Vincent wasn't able to give L.A. much, if anything, on offense. He missed all but one of his six shot attempts and ended up with three points and one assist in 23 minutes.

James was 1-of-7 in the first quarter and 3-of-12 in the first half, and while he shot somewhat better afterward, he never truly got it going. He finished with 20 points on 6-of-16 shooting from the field, although he did make all seven of his free throw attempts. James did help out with nine rebounds, eight assists, two blocks and one steal.

Hachimura made a nice offensive contribution off the bench in 19 minutes. He made four of his seven shot attempts to score 11 points, to go along with one rebound, one assist and two steals.

In 18 minutes, Vanderbilt made all three of his shots to score six points and added two rebounds, one assist and one block.

Timme, a 6-foot-10 power forward who is on a two-way contract, had a fantastic outing and made the most of his 29 minutes of playing time. He shot 9-of-12 overall and 3-of-4 from downtown, giving him 21 points, and he mixed it up well by scoring deep in the paint and also hitting from the perimeter. He also had four assists, two rebounds and two steals.

At times, Bufkin hustled well on defense, resulting in two blocks, and on the other end of the floor, he made three of his eight shot attempts, giving him nine points in 22 minutes. He also chipped in one rebound and one assist.

Smith got 10 minutes of playing time on Saturday and finished with five points on 2-of-3 shooting and three assists.

Knecht played five minutes and hit a 3-pointer, while the younger James got eight minutes on the court and missed both of his shot attempts while notching one assist.

This article originally appeared on LeBron Wire: Lakers player grades: L.A. loses big in Portland while short-handed

title: Top Seahawks takeaways from 41-6 blowout Divisional Round playoff game
description: What stood out the most for Seattle?
fullText:
The Seattle Seahawks dismantled the San Francisco 49ers in literally every phase of the game. In fact, this was tied for their most dominant playoff victory of all time, right alongside Super Bowl XLVIII.

Seattle began the game with a bang, thanks to Rashid Shaheed's 95-yard kick return touchdown. From there, they never let their foot of the pedal for the remainder of the contest. The Seahawks ended San Francisco's season, and now they get to host the NFC Championship for the fourth time ever... and the first since the 2014 season. As always, we at Seahawks Wire take you through the top takeaways from each game, and we aren't slowing down now!

One game is one thing. Two is another. Three, and now four, is officially a pattern. Saturday night marked the fourth-straight game the Seahawks have rushed for at 160+ yards as a team. Against the 49ers, Seattle bulldozed their way to 175 on 33 carries. Leading the way was Kenneth Walker III, who had 116 of those yards and all three rushing touchdowns from the night. Backup Zach Charbonnet did leave the game with an injury and was unable to return, but head coach Mike Macdonald seemed optimistic about initial results.

Sam Darnold has been battling negative bias from the media and opposing fans all season long. This stems from how poorly he played in the Vikings' last two games to conclude the 2024 campaign - blowout losses in Week 18 and the Wild Card. Darnold proved doubters wrong with wins over the Rams and Niners to close out the 2025 season, but doubts persisted, especially with his sudden oblique issue landing him on the injury report. Darnold was totally solid on Saturday. He may not have blown anyone away, but with how this team is playing, completing 12-of-17 passes for 124 yards and a touchdown (a spectacular one at that!) is more than enough to keep the Seahawks competitive. Darnold will most assuredly continue to face these questions, although there may be less of them going into the NFC Championship.

Kupp has not been utilized this year like he had been throughout his time with the LA Rams. An outsider who does not watch Seahawks games each week might even be forgiven for thinking he's not much of an impact player anymore. However, for those who do, know what Kupp brings to the Seahawks. Against the 49ers, the Eastern Washington native reminded everyone he is a veteran with plenty of playoff experience. Kupp led Seattle with 60 yards on five receptions and gave the offense a presense at wide receiver opposite Jaxon Smith-Njigba the team needed.

As I mentioned in the introduction, the Seahawks are going to be playing in their fourth ever NFC Championship game. The three previous ones have all taken place at Qwest/CenturyLink/Lumen Field, and now a fourth will join the trio. Of course, I wouldn't be doing my job if I didn't mention the Seahawks proved to be 3-0 in all of those NFC title games. Whoever emerges from the Rams/Bears game on Sunday will likely be considered a slim underdog at Lumen Field next week, and understandably so.

It's absurd he has never won this award yet. Think about what John Schneider brought to the Seahawks this year: Sam Darnold, Cooper Kupp, and DeMarcus Lawrence - who forced yet another fumble on Saturday night. Keep in mind Darnold and Kupp were replacements for Geno Smith and DK Metcalf. Not to mention the draft pick they received from Metcalf eventually became Nick Emmanwori, who recovered said fumble from Lawrence. Oh, let's not forget the Seahawks acquired Rashid Shaheed at the deadline. Getting a receiver was no on one's radar, but Schneider identified a way to elevate his team, and Shaheed has rewarded his faith with three return touchdowns in seven games. An absolute game changer. Also, even though they weren't this year, two other trade deadline acquisitions in the form of Leonard Williams and Ernest Jones IV were All-Pro players this year. Lastly, two of his previous first round picks from 2023, Devon Witherspoon and Jaxon Smith-Njigba, both made the Pro Bowl, and JSN was even first team All-Pro. There is simply no one else more deserving of the award, and the blowout win over San Francisco was seeing his mastery all pay off in one game.

This article originally appeared on Seahawks Wire: Seahawks vs 49ers: Top Seattle takeaways from Divisional Round

title: Who is Arthur Fery? British qualifier knocks out 20th seed on Australian Open debut
description: The French-born Fery, who is the son of a former tennis player and the president of football club Lorient, stunned an ill Flavio Cobolli on his main draw debut
fullText:
Great Britain‚Äôs Arthur Fery claimed the first upset of the Australian Open as the qualifier knocked out 20th seed Flavio Cobolli in the first round.

The 23-year-old Fery, making his overseas grand slam debut, won 7-6 (1), 6-4, 6-1 to take out the rising star Cobolli, who took a medical timeout and was visited by the doctor as he struggled with a stomach bug.

Fery won his first-round match at last year‚Äôs Wimbledon, also beating the 20th seed in Australia‚Äôs Alexei Popyrin, after receiving a wildcard into the tournament.

This time, Fery has now scored four victories so far in Melbourne, having come through from the first round of qualifying, and will now take on Argentina‚Äôs Tomas Mart√≠n Etcheverry in the second round.

‚ÄúIt seems I like drawing 20th seeds at grand slams,‚Äù Fery laughed afterwards during his on-court interview. ‚ÄúI felt great. I felt very comfortable on that court. Obviously playing three matches beforehand in quallies really helped.‚Äù

Ranked 186th in the world, Fery was born in France and his mother, Olivia Fery, was a professional tennis player. His father, Loic Fery, is a businessman and president of French top-flight football club FC Lorient.

‚ÄúIt definitely really helped when I was younger in my development to have two parents who know how pro-sport works and the pressures of it,‚Äù said Fery, who is also fluent in French due to his parents.

‚ÄúKeeping a good balance between trying to develop tennis but also having a life and having an education and keeping your kid balanced when he is young. It‚Äôs very important. I'm very lucky for that.‚Äù

He went to school at King College in Wimbledon before enrolling at Stanford University in the United States on a tennis scholarship, a route also taken by the British No 2 Cameron Norrie and No 3 Jacob Fearnley (both Texas Christian University) in recent years.

Fery played for three years at Stanford, between 2020 and 2023, while also studying for a degree in science and technology, and became the No 1 ranked singles player in the college system during his second year.

‚ÄúIt was a good experience. It's very different to going pro straightaway,‚Äù Fery said. ‚ÄúI think I wasn't quite ready for the pro tour at 18 when I came out of juniors.

‚ÄúI wasn't ready to travel 35, 40 weeks a year. So college was a great experience. You obviously get a world-class education at Stanford. At the same time you can play loads of matches, develop as a player.

‚ÄúYou are left to your own a little bit more than if you have a travelling coach all the time with you. It's character-building for sure. I was lucky, very lucky, to be around great people and great coaches.

‚ÄúIt's very individual. Some guys are ready to go all guns blazing 35 weeks a year travelling with a coach, or without. That's their identity. They are a tennis player from 18.

‚ÄúI was still in normal school until 16. I did A-levels, home school at home playing juniors. Tennis wasn't my life at 18. Now I feel like it is. It's my job.‚Äù

Fery made two appearances in the main draw at Wimbledon, his home tournament, before earning his first win over Popyrin at last year‚Äôs Championships. He lost to Luciano Darderi in the second round.

But Fery also took a step forwards in his career in September when he replaced the British No 1 Jack Draper and the injured Fearnley in Great Britain‚Äôs Davis Cup tie against Poland, beating Olaf Pieczkowski 6-4 6-2 in Gdynia.

Along with his first title on the Challenger circuit, Fery entered the 2026 season with a career-high ranking of 185 in the world - although he is already set to gain more than 50 places after beating Cobolli in the first round of the Australian Open.

The French-born Fery also said it was ‚Äúsatisfying‚Äù to produce a big result at the grand slams away from Wimbledon, where British players can receive wildcards and have the backing of the home crowds.

‚ÄúObviously when you see the draw, you play a seed, you know you need your best tennis to get through. Maybe it was a good thing for me as well to know that I had to really play well and bring my best tennis today to have a chance. I thought I did that. I felt really at that level.

‚ÄúI was already happy to qualify here for my first time in the quallies of a slam on my own. Now coming through quallies and winning a round, I'm proud of it. I was hoping that at some point I was going to be able to play other slams without needing wildcards. So that's a good step forward for my career for sure.‚Äù

After qualifying for the main draw, Fery‚Äôs mum flew out to Australia just in time for his match against Cobolli.

‚ÄúWhen I won that last round, she asked me if she could come,‚Äù Fery said. ‚ÄúIt's obviously it's a long way, but at least I made it worth it. She can see at least two matches - hopefully more.‚Äù

Argentina‚Äôs Etcheverry, who has a career-high ranking of 27 and beat Andy Murray on his final-ever match at the Australian Open.

Etcheverry battled past Miomir Kecmanovic in five sets and Fery said: ‚ÄúHe's been on tour for a while, so I know him. I've seen some matches, but not too much. I guess we'll speak about it with my coach and come with a good game plan.‚Äù

title: Beckett Sennecke sets up Mikael Granlund in OT, Ducks beat Kings 2-1 for weekend sweep
description: Mikael Granlund scored at 4:02 of overtime, and the Anaheim Ducks beat the Los Angeles Kings 2-1 on Saturday night to sweep a two-game weekend set in the Freeway Faceoff rivalry.  Rookie Beckett Sennecke created the winning score by swooping in on a backcheck to take the puck away from Los Angeles' Kevin Fiala on a breakaway.  Sennecke knocked the puck straight to Granlund, who beat Anton Forsberg for his ninth goal of the season.
fullText:
ANAHEIM, Calif. (AP) ‚Äî Mikael Granlund scored at 4:02 of overtime, and the Anaheim Ducks beat the Los Angeles Kings 2-1 on Saturday night to sweep a two-game weekend set in the Freeway Faceoff rivalry.

Rookie Beckett Sennecke created the winning score by swooping in on a backcheck to take the puck away from Los Angeles' Kevin Fiala on a breakaway. Sennecke knocked the puck straight to Granlund, who beat Anton Forsberg for his ninth goal of the season.

Mason McTavish scored the first goal and Ville Husso made 17 saves for the Ducks. They have won three straight after a nine-game skid.

Adrian Kempe scored a power-play goal and Forsberg stopped 30 shots in the backup's strong performance for the Kings, who have lost six of seven.

Sennecke played a major role for the second straight night when the Southern California clubs completed their back-to-back set by going to overtime for the third time in their four meetings this season. Sennecke had two assists and scored in the shootout as the Ducks rallied from a two-goal deficit for a 3-2 victory over the Kings in downtown Los Angeles on Friday night.

McTavish ended the Ducks' victory in LA with his fourth shootout goal of the season, and he opened the scoring in the rematch with a wrist shot for his 12th goal early in the first period.

Kempe tied it in the second period, scoring his 16th goal on a hard one-timer off a pass from Fiala. Kempe then put a gloved finger to his lips, shushing the sixth consecutive sellout crowd in Anaheim.

Los Angeles had six power plays before the Ducks got their first man-advantage late in the second period, yet Anaheim had a significant edge in shots after carrying play for long stretches at even strength.

After a scoreless third, the Kings played into extra time for a league-high 20th time this season.

Jeffrey Viel made his debut for the Ducks, who traded a fourth-round pick to Boston on Friday to get the veteran forward who hasn't scored in the NHL since March 18, 2022. The 6-foot-1 Viel fought 6-foot-6 Kings forward Samuel Helenius in the first period.

Kings: Host the New York Rangers on Tuesday night.

Ducks: Host the Rangers on Monday night.

title: Jalen Williams sustains thigh injury in Thunder's 122-120 loss to Heat
description: Jalen Williams sustains thigh injury in Oklahoma City Thunder's 122-120 loss to Miami Heat.
fullText:
Driving to the basket, Jalen Williams immediately knew something was wrong. He grabbed his hamstring and asked for a substitution. Hobbling to the locker room, his injury clouded the Oklahoma City Thunder for the rest of the way in their 122-120 loss to the Miami Heat.

Williams sustained the injury in the second quarter. Ajay Mitchell started the second half in his place. Eventually, the Thunder ruled him out for the remainder of the game due to right thigh soreness.

Thunder head coach Mark Daigneault said afterward they'll know 

Over the last handful of games, Williams has played his best basketball of the season. He's continued to work back from his surgically-repaired wrist. Now, you hope he doesn't miss too much time with his injury.

If so, that obviously is a bummer for the Thunder. Williams missed OKC's first 19 games recovering from his torn wrist ligaments that he played through in their championship run these past playoffs. They went 18-1 in that stretch.

This article originally appeared on OKC Thunder Wire: Jalen Williams sustains thigh injury in Thunder's 122-120 loss to Heat

title: Chelsea interested in Ivory Coast winger with 3 goals in 9 games for his country
description: Chelsea are reportedly interested in signing an Ivory Coast winger who has 3 goals in 9 games for his country so far.It‚Äôs actually his only 9 games he‚Äôs had for Ivory Coast so far, having come up ...
fullText:
Chelsea are reportedly interested in signing an Ivory Coast winger who has 3 goals in 9 games for his country so far.

It‚Äôs actually his only 9 games he‚Äôs had for Ivory Coast so far, having come up through the youth teams of his national side first.

Chelsea are mostly being linked with new centre backs right now for this transfer window, but we are hearing a lot about other positions being targeted in the summer probably, as well as any potential more opportunities arising this window.

January is a long month so they have plenty of time still to get some deals done, but this story is more than likely going to be one for the summer, of they do decide to make an attempt to try and sign him

Yan Diomande playing for RB Leipzig. (Photo by Stuart Franklin/Getty Images)

According to Sky Germany, Chelsea among top clubs interested in RB Leipzig‚Äôs winger Yan Diomande.

The 19-year-old left winger has only been at Leipzig since the summer but already there are talks of the big clubs coming in for him ‚Äì Chelsea being one of them.

We‚Äôll see if anything goes any further on this one, but it‚Äôs clear that if this is a transfer that is going to happen then it will be for the summer of 2026 rather than this window now.

Obviously we had a game on yesterday with Chelsea beating Brentford 2-0 at Stamford Bridge in their latest Premier League match. It was a needed win, but it might have come at the cost of another injury to a defender, with Liam Rosenior putting the latest out on that after the game yesterday afternoon.

Cole Palmer‚Äôs poor recent form continued yesterday, but Rosenior has defended his attacking midfielder in the media and denied any suggestion of poor form.

title: Tough Breaks For American Teams at Dakar
description: Brabec misses winning by 2 seconds, Ford Raptors get lost, but American Polaris team wins again
fullText:
A series of unfortunate events wound up costing American Honda rider Ricky Brabec the win in the motorcycle class of the 2026 Dakar rally, a race held for the seventh year in Saudi Arabia.

After two weeks of racing over countless miles of sand and rocks, Argentine Luciano Benavides, riding a KTM, edged out American Ricky Brabec‚Äôs Honda by two seconds, the narrowest margin in the history of the event.

It was just the final cruel twist of fate Dakar had to deal out.

‚ÄúI have no idea why we lost, it makes no sense to me,‚Äù said two-time winner Brabec at the finish line, after he had congratulated Benavides.

Ah, but we have an idea. Several.

First was camels. Brabec came upon a herd he estimated at 50-strong way out in a rocky section of that day‚Äôs stage. He couldn‚Äôt go around them because of the big rocks on either side of the dirt road, he couldn‚Äôt go through them because camels are really big, and he couldn‚Äôt even honk a horn because race bikes don‚Äôt have horns.

‚ÄúThe camels were freakin‚Äô in the road and I couldn‚Äôt go around them. I was like, ‚ÄòDamn, I don‚Äôt know what to do. I‚Äôm losing time right here.‚Äô There were probably, like, 50 camels, right? So I‚Äôm like, ‚ÄòDude I can‚Äôt go around, there‚Äôs, like, big black boulder rocks just everywhere,‚Äô and I was like, ‚ÄòIf I go out and try to risk going around the camels I‚Äôm gonna make it (the motorcycle) tip over, maybe smash something, twist an ankle or just something so stupid,‚Äô so I just sat behind ‚Äòem and I tried to get as close as I can and maybe they would shoo and go anywhere in the rocks. But yeah I was kinda bummed about this situation.‚Äù

Then, on another day‚Äôs stage, Brabec stopped again, this time to help a fallen competitor. Australian KTM rider Daniel Sanders crashed 138 kilometers into the second half of Wednesday's marathon stage from Wadi ad Dawasir to Bisha, breaking his collarbone and sternum, according to abc.au.

‚ÄúI came over the dune and Tosh (Spanish Honda rider Tosha Schareina) came over the dune, and he (Sanders) was just kind of under his bike, stuck,‚Äù Brabec said. ‚ÄúSo me and Tosh stopped. Tosh stopped at the top of the dune to make sure no one was coming to jump and land on him. Then I was down in the dune helping Daniel.‚Äù

He got that sorted out but, in the process, lost the lead. Sanders, being a tough Australian, got back on his bike‚Ä¶ and finished the stage.

Nor did Brabec. He regained the lead in the following days and, until, just two kliks from the finish line, when he was in the lead by over three minutes and had only to cruise his Monster Energy Honda to the inflatable Red Bull arch and take his third Dakar win, something happened.

‚ÄúI navigated well all day,‚Äù Brabec said. ‚ÄúOne route note, right here, two kilometers from the finish, I don‚Äôt know. I took the wrong left. The route book showed one left, so I took the left. It put me in a bad situation, and here we are.‚Äù

On the four-wheeled side of Dakar, meanwhile, it was a Dacia that won. Dacias are one of the cheapest cars you can buy in Europe, and the one you give a big sigh over when they assign it to you at the car rental counter at Charles de Gaulle. The somewhat diminutive Dacia Sandrider prototype looked like a little bug, but won it all over the mighty 2026 Ford Raptor T1 Ultimate Dakar Rally car and the equally mighty (and last year‚Äôs winner) Toyota Hilux.

It helped that it was driven by Qatari driver Nasser Al Attiyah, who had already won Dakar five times, this year making six.

Ford showed up at Dakar with four factory entries, while an additional four privateers also drove Raptors. It was the first year Ford came as an official factory team.

The trucks, too, had been upgraded.

‚ÄúThe Ford Raptor T1+ itself represents the most complete expression yet of what we‚Äôve learned through years of desert racing,‚Äù Ford said before the race. ‚ÄúIt is lighter, more aerodynamically efficient, delivers dramatically improved visibility and control, and incorporates meaningful gains in suspension performance, cockpit access, and overall durability.‚Äù

In the early stages, Ford was doing well, swapping wins with Toyota‚Äôs Hilux trucks. But both Ford and Toyota didn‚Äôt show enough wins to last at the top of the leaderboard, and all the time Al Attiyah was moving up. While he won Stage 2, by his Stage 6 win, he seemed in strong contention to win it all. And despite Ford winning five stages and the prologue, navigation errors by Ford drivers, and smoother running by Al Attiyah throughout, meant the Qatari driver was the winner.

In SxS competition, as in Baja, it was American Brock Heger in the Loeb Fraymedia Motorsport Polaris RZR Factory Racing entry that claimed his second Dakar win in the class, after doing the same dominating dance in SCORE desert racing in Baja.

In the Stock class it was Defender Rally in its debut year, as drivers Rokas Baciu≈°ka and Oriol Vidal win in the Defender Dakar D7X‚ÄëR. Teammates Sara Price and Sean Berriman finished in second place, while ‚ÄòMr Dakar‚Äô St√©phane Peterhansel and co‚Äëdriver Mika Metge finished in fourth position in the Dakar Rally Stock class rankings.

‚ÄúDakar Rally was just incredible,‚Äù said Price. ‚ÄúWe had a goal at the final stage to get to the finish line as a team together. So to see the whole Defender team sitting there at the finish line and all their excitement and emotions, it just shows what this is all about and what it means. To get this team to the finish line in P1 and P2 is just, wow, incredible.‚Äù

As was the whole two-week adventure. If you can‚Äôt get enough of this off-road stuff, the SCORE King Shocks San Felipe 250 starts March 25-29 in Baja. But that‚Äôs an entirely different kind of racing.

title: The Seahawks showed the 49ers, entire NFL they are a runaway freight train
description: Get out of the way or you‚Äôre going to get run over by the Seahawks!
fullText:
That was supremely satisfying. Mike Macdonald loves his rallying cries, whether it‚Äôs ‚Äú12 as one‚Äù, ‚ÄúChasing Edges,‚Äù or ‚ÄúE.A.T.‚Äù. I‚Äôve got another one for the Seattle Seahawks after that 41-6 dismantling of the San Francisco 49ers in the Division Round ‚Äì Professional Destruction.

Those two words embody Macdonald‚Äôs vision for the team and perfectly encapsulate the way Seattle has been playing for the last two months. ‚ÄòThe Dark Side‚Äù defense has been utterly suffocating opposing offenses while the running game has been on a roll. For weeks I‚Äôve been trying to find different ways to describe the dominance the Seahawks have been showcasing, particularly on the defensive side. The way Ken Walker is running behind this nasty offensive line, the offense also fully deserves the Professional Destruction moniker.

Ken Walker III is really damn good‚Ä¶historically good for the Seahawks playoffs actually.

@Seahawks RB Kenneth Walker III tied the postseason franchise record with three rushing touchdowns. #GoHawks

‚Äî Seahawks PR (@seahawksPR) January 18, 2026

The offensive line was giving him good creases and Walker was hitting the hole with burst. He also had some fantastic cutbacks and broke tackles on the way. Maybe the most emblematic run of how the Seahawks are playing right now was the one in the fourth quarter where he ran into a crowd and got pushed about five yards farther when the rest of the team got in on the action. The Seahawks are physically imposing their will on the opponents. I would take his stat line of 19 carries for 116 yards and 3 TDs any day.

Ernest Jones IV is really damn good. He singlehandedly caused two turnovers today, stripping the ball from Jake Tonges on Seattle‚Äôs second defensive drive and picked off Brock Purdy later in the game. He‚Äôs a tackling machine and is the leader in the middle of the defense getting everyone lined up. Picking up Jones in a trade last season is one of the best trades John Schneider has made as GM of the Seahawks.

Rashid Shaheed is really damn good. Speaking of great trades by John Schneider, the Shaheed trade is the gift that keeps on giving. His opening kickoff return for a TD was literally the game-winner, and was his third return TD since joining the Seahawks at the trade deadline. Shaheed also had a huge run on an end-around and drew a pass interference penalty. With Tory Horton‚Äôs injury, adding Shaheed has been a massive key to the Seahawks success this season.

DeMarcus Lawrence is really damn good. He got to Brock Purdy on his first throw of the game, nearly forcing a fumble. Later, he blew up a fourth down play. Even later, he strip-sacked Purdy and the ball was recovered by Nick Emmanwori. Tank came to the Seahawks because he thought they had a chance to win the Super Bowl. He‚Äôs doing his best to make that a reality.

Playoff Cooper Kupp is awesome. His stat line of 5 catches for 60 yards might not be the most impressive, but all of them seemed to come at crucial times. Kupp was the reliable safety blanket that everyone hoped he would be after signing with his hometown team.

The tight ends didn‚Äôt have any catches today, but they all blocked their asses off. AJ Barner and Eric Saubert were both throwing key blocks on the outside runs that Walker was so effective with against the 49ers. That kind of selfless play is why those guys are beloved.

It was good to see Charles Cross and Coby Bryant back out there. Bryant finished the game, unlike Cross, but hopefully it was just precautionary with Charles. Zach Charbonnet was injured as well, but the initial prognosis was somewhat hopeful. He‚Äôs a huge part of the third down packages and a touchdown machine, so having him miss time would hurt the offense.

The offensive line blocked really well again today as evidenced by the 175 yards rushing, the fourth week in a row that Seattle ran for 150+ yards. At this point, I don‚Äôt think it‚Äôs a fluke. No better time for the run game to come alive than at the most important time of the season!

Seattle will host the NFC Championship game for the first time in over a decade and got damn does it feel good! Whether it‚Äôs the third matchup with the Los Angeles Rams or a showdown with the No. 2 seed Chicago Bears, it‚Äôs sure to be a wild atmosphere. Until then, enjoy this one folks. This is a special, special team!

title: What were books like in ancient Greece and Rome?
description: Ancient bookstore were surprisingly modern.
fullText:
This article originally appeared in The Conversation.

If you were to visit a bookshop in the ancient world, what would it be like?

You don‚Äôt just have to imagine it. The ancient Roman writer¬†Aulus Gellius, who lived in the 2nd century CE, gives us a number of descriptions of his adventures at bookstores. In¬†one passage, he describes an encounter at one in Rome, which he was visiting with a poet friend:

I chanced to be sitting in a bookshop in the Sigillaria with the poet Julius Paulus [‚Ä¶] There was on sale there the Annals of¬†Quintus Fabius Pictor¬†in a copy of good and undoubted age, which the dealer maintained was without errors.

Gellius then tells us that, while they are sitting there, another customer enters the shop. The new customer has a disagreement with the dealer. He complains that he ‚Äúfound in the book one error‚Äù. The dealer says that‚Äôs impossible. Then the customer brings out evidence to prove the dealer wrong.

In¬†different passage, Aulus tells us about some bookstalls he came across when he arrived by ship at the port of¬†Brundisium¬†on the Adriatic coast. The books, he records, were ‚Äúin Greek, filled with marvellous tales, things unheard of, incredible [‚Ä¶] The writers were ancient and of no mean authority‚Äù.

The volumes themselves, however, were filthy from neglect, in bad condition and unsightly. Nevertheless, I drew near and asked their price; then, attracted by their extraordinary and unexpected cheapness, I bought a large number of them for a small sum.

Aulus goes on to describe in excited language all the weird facts he derived from these books ‚Äì like how people in Africa can ‚Äúwork spells by voice and tongue‚Äù and through this witchcraft cause people, animals, trees and crops to die.

These sorts of stories bring us close to how ordinary people in ancient Greek and Roman times obtained books and engaged with books. But if we read stories like this it might lead us to want to know more. How did books and writing come into existence? And how were books written and produced?

Many people in the ancient world thought that writing had been invented by gods or heroes. For example, the ancient Egyptians believed the god¬†Thoth¬†was the first to create signs to represent spoken sounds.

The origins of writing are certainly mysterious. It‚Äôs unclear when writing began and who invented it.

The earliest written text is a wooden tablet radiocarbon dated to before 5000 BCE. This is known as the¬†Dispilio tablet, because it was discovered at a neolithic lakeside settlement at Dispilio in Greece. It is carved with strange linear markings. These have not been deciphered, but most scholars think they are a form of writing.

Evidence for writing appears early in different parts of the world. In Mesopotamia and Egypt, the oldest texts, such as the¬†Kish limestone tablet¬†at Uruk or the¬†Narmer Palette¬†at Hierakonpolis, date to before 3000 BCE. In the Indus Valley, the¬†Harappan script, which remains undeciphered, appeared around the same time. In China, the earliest characters, the¬†Dawenkou graphs, also date to around 3000 BCE.

One of the most interesting aspects of early writing is that there is such a variety of different scripts. For example, the earliest known texts in the Greek language are written in the¬†Linear B script, which was used from around 1500-1200 BCE, and wasn‚Äôt deciphered until 1952. Linear B is not an alphabet, but a syllabary of more than 80 different signs. A¬†syllabary¬†is a kind of writing system where each sign represents a syllable.

Our English alphabet comes from the Romans, who in the 8th and 7th century BCE also got their alphabet from the Phoenicians, via the Greeks.

People in ancient times used many different things as writing materials.

The Roman writer¬†Pliny the Elder¬†(23-79 CE)¬†tells us¬†that the earliest people in the world

used to write on palm-leaves and then on the bark of certain trees, and afterwards folding sheets of lead began to be employed for official muniments, and then also sheets of linen or tablets of wax for private documents.

However, the most popular writing material in the ancient Mediterranean was¬†papyrus, from which we get our word ‚Äúpaper‚Äù.

To make papyrus, you get the pith of the papyrus plant (Cyperus papyrus), cut it into slender strips, then press it together. Once dried, it forms a thin sheet that you can write on.

Papyrus sheets were usually glued together into rolls. These rolls could be very long. Some of the most lavish Egyptian papyrus rolls were more than 10 metres long, such as the recently discovered¬†Waziri Papyrus¬†containing parts of the Book of the Dead.

When papyri were rolled up they were stored in shelves or boxes. Labels were attached to the handles of the papyri so you could identify their contents. In his play Linus, Greek playwright¬†Alexis¬†(c. 375-275 BC) has one character tell another how to¬†look through¬†a bunch of rolls to find what he wants:

go over and pick any papyrus roll you like out of there and then read it‚Ä¶ examining them quietly, and at your leisure, on the basis of the labels. Orpheus is in there, Hesiod, tragedies, Choerilus, Homer, Epicharmus, prose treatises of every type‚Ä¶

Papyrus seems flimsy to the eye, but it is a durable writing material, stronger than modern paper. Many papyri have survived for thousands of years stored in jars or sarcophagi or buried under the sand.

The oldest surviving papyrus text is the so-called¬†Diary of Merer¬†(which you can listen to¬†here), the logbook of a man named Merer, who was an inspector during the construction of the Great Pyramid of Giza under Pharaoh Khufu. This papyrus, which dates to around 2600 BCE, gives a day-by-day account of how Merer and his team of about 200 men spent time hauling and transporting stone and doing other work.

Papyrus was susceptible to being eaten by insects or mice. But there were ways to prevent this. Pliny the Elder, for example,¬†advises¬†that sheets of papyrus soaked in citrus-oil won‚Äôt be eaten by moths.

If you were living in ancient Greece or Rome and wanted to write a book, how would you do it?

First, you would buy sheets or rolls of papyrus to write on. If you couldn‚Äôt afford it, you‚Äôd have to write on the back or in the margins of papyri you already owned.

If you didn‚Äôt own any papyri already, then you would have to write on other materials.¬†According to¬†the Greek historian¬†Diogenes Laertius¬†(3rd century CE), the philosopher¬†Cleanthes¬†(c. 331-231 BCE) ‚Äúwrote down lectures on oyster-shells and the blade-bones of oxen through lack of money to buy papyrus‚Äù.

Second, you would get your ink. In the ancient world, there were¬†many varieties of ink. Normal black ink was made from the soot of burnt resin or pitch mixed with vegetable gum. When buying ink, it would come in powder form, and you would need to mix it with water before using it.

Third, you would get your pen. It would be made from reed, hence it was called the ‚Äúcalamus‚Äù by Greeks and Romans (‚Äúcalamus‚Äù is the Greek word for reed). To sharpen your pen you would need a knife. If you made a mistake, you would erase it with a wet sponge.

Now you have all the materials you need. However, you don‚Äôt need to use the pen and papyrus yourself. If you want, you can get a scribe to write down your words for you.

The Greek orator¬†Dio Chrysostom¬†(c.40-110 CE) even¬†advised¬†writers not to use the pen themselves:

Writing I do not advise you to engage in with your own hand, or only very rarely, but rather to dictate to a secretary.

If you needed to consult other books while writing, you could get friends to send them to you or ask book dealers to make you a copy. In a papyrus from the 2nd century CE found at Oxyrhynchus, Egypt, and written in Greek, the writer¬†asks¬†his friend to find the books that he needs and make copies of them. Otherwise, you would go to a library, though the best libraries at Alexandria, Rome and Athens might be far away.

When you finished drafting your book you would need to revise and correct it. You could then publish it by having many copies made by scribes and delivering these copies to friends and booksellers.

When all this was done, your book would be out in public. Perhaps someone like Aulus Gellius would stumble across it in a busy Roman bookshop. Maybe he‚Äôd even buy it.
